And while the midterms went fairly smoothly, many leaders are still moving to make it harder to vote, further undermining the already gutted VRA, and sowing mistrust in our elections. Protecting democracy is a long-haul fight.

I’m also hoping the Senate takes action by the end of the year to get the Electoral Count Act done, which will help clear up antiquated election laws so we don’t have the type of chaos we saw on Jan. 6 ever again.
I’ll be closely watching the outcome of that case, Moore v. Harper, which will be argued next week.

Many of these election deniers will be in office as state legislators, which is particularly fraught as the Supreme Court is poised to hear a case that could give legislatures more power to subvert elections over the will of voters, courts, and state constitutions.

I am remaining vigilant that election subversion remains possible – either as certification continues or in elections down the line. While a lot of high-profile candidates lost, election deniers were elected (or reelected) up and down the ballot, and they will have power.

I want to commend the brave actions of election workers across the country, who confronted the threat to our elections head on. It is thanks to their commitment to upholding democracy that we had such a smooth process.

There are some worrying signs, however. A handful of counties resisted certification of the final vote. And angry crowds protested vote certification processes across the country. The certification of the statewide vote in Michigan, for example, was briefly disrupted.

First of all, a lot of the news is good. Elections were largely peaceful, open, and fair. Many high-profile election deniers lost their races. Most certification processes across the nation appear, for the most part, to be going smoothly.
